questions.question: Consider the linear transformation T: R<sup>2</sup>→R<sup>2</sup> defined by T(x, y)=(x, 0), where x, y∈R. Then range of T is
Consider the linear transformation T: R<sup>3</sup>→R<sup>2</sup> defined by T(x, y, z)=(x, y+z), where x, y, z∈R. Then range of T is
Consider the linear transformation T:R<sup>2</sup>→R<sup>2</sup> defined by T(x, y)=(x, -y), where x, y∈R. Then

answers.b: T is onto, but not one-to-one
answers.c: T is neither one-to-one nor onto

questions.question: Consider the linear transformation T:R<sup>3</sup>→R<sup>2</sup> defined by T(x, y, z)=(x+y+z, 0), where x, y, z∈R. Then
Consider the map T:R<sup>2</sup>→R<sup>3</sup> such that T(1, 3)=(1, 0, 0), T(2, 6)=(2, 0, 0), T(1, 1)=(0, 1, 0) and T(2, 4)=(1, 1, 0). Then T is

Consider the map T:R<sup>2</sup>→R<sup>2</sup> and S:R<sup>2</sup>→R<sup>2</sup> such that T(2, 1)=(1, 1), T(1, 2)=(1, 1), S(4, 2)=(3, 3) and S(8, 4)=(5, 6). Let the statements A and B be as given below:
A: T is one-to-one.
B: S is not linear.
Then which of following holds

answers.a: A is true, B is false
answers.b: A is false, B is true
answers.c: A is true, B is true
answers.d: A is false, B is false
